author: Marissa Greene
title: How Tarrant County faith leaders tackle mental health inside and outside church walls
text:
LaVerne Campbell was born to serve.
Her mission carried on even after she retired from her 50-year nursing career in 2018. Now, she is applying her skillset at Beth Eden Baptist Church in southeast Fort Worth as its faith community nurse.
In addition to tending to minor cuts and scratches, she and other nurses in the church are often a resource for general education on diseases. Congregants in Campbell‚Äôs church have her on speed dial, she said, for support or referrals for other kinds of professional help.
Campbell said that her church‚Äôs nursing ministry was reduced from eight members to three after the COVID-19 pandemic. The physical and emotional demand of caring for congregants with chronic health issues such as diabetes, hypertension and autoimmune diseases with her smaller team can sometimes be ‚Äúoverwhelming,‚Äù she said.
Campbell is not alone. She was one of many laypeople who attended the Texas Health Community Hope Faith Summit. The April 22 event was designed to offer fellowship to people in both the faith and health fields while discussing topics like mental health, congregational welfare and sustaining health ministries in North Texas.
‚ÄúI love what I do. I love tending to their needs, and I love being able to see them get better and change their lifestyle,‚Äù Campbell said. ‚ÄúBut I have to intentionally unplug, and sometimes I don‚Äôt always do that for myself, so it was a good reminder of the caregiver needing to unplug and learn to say no and just take really good care of yourself.‚Äù
Religious leaders are not immune to experiencing mental illnesses and challenges. In 2015, 46% of clergy surveyed by the evangelical Christian polling firm Barna Group said that they had experienced depression at some point during their ministry. That number increased to 59% by 2020, according to the report .
About 350 people attended the Texas Health Community Hope Faith Summit on April 22, 2025, said David Tesmer, chief community and public policy officer for Texas Health Resources. (Marissa Greene | Fort Worth Report) Mental health and well-being is a ‚Äúmajor issue for North Texas communities,‚Äù said David Tesmer, chief community and public policy officer for the faith-based system Texas Health Resources.
The nonprofit‚Äôs Faith Summit is a way to bring faith and health leaders together to share their experiences and learn about resources available to them from Texas Health Resources and other organizations at Tuesday‚Äôs event, he said.
‚ÄúThey take on a lot,‚Äù Tesmer said. ‚ÄúThey hear a lot about problems that individuals want to come in and talk to them about. Their cup kind of gets empty and they need to fill their cup up. So they‚Äôre asking us, ‚ÄòHow can we take better care of ourselves so we can take care of others?‚Äô‚Äù
Campbell and others gathered inside the Hurst Conference Center discussed the emotional toll of ministry. Four Tarrant County pastors shared how they try to keep themselves healthy in the pursuit of their role of ministering to their congregants.
‚ÄúSelf-care has to start with the community,‚Äù said the Rev. Ralph S. Emerson, pastor of Rising Star Baptist Church located in southeast Fort Worth. He recommended having three tiers of connectivity.
‚ÄúYou need somebody above you, who holds you accountable. ‚Ä¶ You need to have somebody beneath you that you can pour out into that responsibility for you to attend to them,‚Äù Emerson said. ‚ÄúAnd I think you just need good people connected to you, a real group of people who can kind of just sit and listen to you.‚Äù
The Rev. Ralph S. Emerson, pastor of Rising Star Baptist Church, speaks during a panel at Texas Health Community Hope Faith Summit on April 22, 2025. (Marissa Greene | Fort Worth Report) It can be challenging to find time for yourself as a bi-vocational pastor, said the Rev. Dr. Gilbert Marez of Camino de Paz Christian Church, located near Fort Worth‚Äôs Oakhurst neighborhood.
Bi-vocational pastors have the same duties as full-time pastors but hold a second non-church job to supplement their ministry income.
In Marez‚Äôs experience, many Latino pastors work bi-vocationally because ‚Äúchurches are small, many of our parishioners are low-to-moderate income,‚Äù he said.
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre trying to do two or three things at the same time, never mind the fact that you‚Äôre doing baptisms, you‚Äôre doing quincea√±eras, you‚Äôre doing weddings, you‚Äôre doing counseling,‚Äù Marez said. ‚ÄúIt gets very difficult to try to set some sort of standard.‚Äù
Finding time to take breaks within the day can help, Marez said.
The Rev. Dr. Gilbert Marez shares how he navigates his mental health as a bi-vocational pastor for Camino de Paz Christian Church during a panel at the Texas Health Community Hope Faith Summit on April 22, 2025. (Marissa Greene | Fort Worth Report) Understanding how your soul functions in the world will help you know how to rest, said the Rev. Johnny Brower, lead pastor of First United Methodist Church of Hurst. Taking personality tests like the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator assessment , or the Enneagram test can be the building blocks of understanding yourself better, he said.
‚ÄúWhen you have self-awareness, you understand how you move in the world, why certain things trigger you, why certain things upset you or make you sad,‚Äù Brower said. ‚ÄúInstead of just going ‚ÄòOh gosh, what‚Äôs happening there?‚Äô I begin to know. So not only can I give grace to others, I can give grace to myself and not beat myself up.‚Äù
The Rev. David Grebel, interim pastor of Celebration Community Church, tells attendees during a Texas Health Community Hope Faith Summit panel how taking a sabbatical helped his mental health. (Marissa Greene | Fort Worth Report) The Rev. Johnny Brower, lead pastor of First United Methodist Church of Hurst, talks about how building self-awareness can help with mental health during the Texas Health Community Hope Faith Summit. (Marissa Greene | Fort Worth Report) Before the Rev. David Grebel became interim pastor of Celebration Community Church in southwest Fort Worth; he spent decades working a mix of higher education and pastoral roles.
When it comes to thinking about how to stay in ministry for the long haul, taking a sabbatical helps, Grebel said.
‚ÄúI had the chance to stop and think through again who I wanted to be theologically, who I wanted to be as a pastor, who I wanted to be as a person,‚Äù Grebel said. ‚ÄúSo for me, the biggest self-care thing is learning how to step away so I can step back in.‚Äù
As health ministry work continues to evolve, Campbell appreciates the fresh perspectives she got from the pastors, she said. She plans to take everything she learned to help her continue serving her church ‚Äî something she doesn‚Äôt plan on stopping anytime soon.
‚ÄúI have to keep doing it, even though I don‚Äôt get paid to do this. It doesn‚Äôt matter,‚Äù Campbell said. ‚ÄúI love serving, because I know that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm supposed to do.‚Äù
Marissa Greene is a Report for America corps member, covering faith for the Fort Worth Report. You can contact her at marissa.greene@fortworthreport.org. At the Fort Worth Report, news decisions are made independently of our board members and financial supporters. Read more about our editorial independence policy here .

author: Jacob Adams
title: David Hogg's Candidate Loses in Arizona
text:
It wasn‚Äôt good news for the David Hogg-backed candidate Deja Foxx as the votes came in late last night in the race to be the Democrat nominee to fill Arizona‚Äôs 7th Congressional District seat.
Foxx, who gained notoriety for her pointed remarks to then-Arizona Sen. Jeff Flake in 2017, had been touted by the mainstream press as a real challenger to the perceived favorite Adelita Grijalva, the daughter of Rep. Ra√∫l M. Grijalva, D-Ariz., whose death in office prompted the special primary and general election to replace him.
With about 77% of the vote tabulated in the special primary election, the 25-year-old influencer fell spectacularly short of winning the race. Instead, Grijalva is on track to win an outright majority of the vote in the race for her father‚Äôs old seat. Grijalva has marshaled about 62% of the vote compared to Foxx‚Äôs approximately 21% and former congressional intern Daniel Hernandez‚Äôs 14%.
Foxx‚Äôs race was a bellwether case for whether Hogg‚Äôs political action committee‚ÄîLeaders We Deserve‚Äîcould make the difference in elevating younger activist-type candidates over the Democrat establishment . Indeed, Hogg‚Äôs organization is expected to spend a total of about $20 million by 2026‚Äôs conclusion.
Foxx‚Äôs defeat is another hurdle for Hogg who left his position as a vice chair of the Democratic National Committee after just a few months on the job after he declined to sign a pledge promulgated by DNC Chair Ken Martin to remain neutral in Democrat primaries.
‚ÄúI came into this role to play a positive role in creating the change our party needs. It is clear that there is a fundamental disagreement about the role of a vice chair‚Äîand it‚Äôs OK to have disagreements. What isn‚Äôt OK is allowing this to remain our focus when there is so much more we need to be focused on,‚Äù Hogg said in a statement around the time of his DNC departure.

Retail Ambition and a New Shopping Era (1950s) In the early 1950s, developers set their sights on San Leandro, California, as a prime location for a modern retail hub. The site chosen for this venture held a unique past‚Äîit was once home to the Oakland Speedway, a well-known automobile racing stadium.

title: NOAA Weather Radio transmitters are down across Omaha area, crews working to find cause
text:

I THINK LUKE YEAH, SO MANY STRONG WINDS AND WE‚ÄôRE COMPARING THEM TO HURRICANE FORCE WINDS A LOT. AND THEY WERE THEY WERE GETTING CLOSE TO ALMOST. HURRICANE TWO STATUS AT THE PEAK OF THIS LINE OF STORMS THAT CAME THROUGH. IF YOU GET A 95 MILE PER HOUR WIND, OUR HIGHEST REPORT WAS 92, BUT 95 WOULD BE HURRICANE TWO STATUS. SO THAT SHOULD HELP DRY US OUT A LITTLE BIT. AND NOW THAT THIS SYSTEM IS WELL OFF TO OUR EAST, THAT‚ÄôS WHAT SPARKED THE STORMS YESTERDAY. WE HAVE THIS NORTH WIND THAT‚ÄôS COMING BEHIND IT. SO THAT‚ÄôS USUALLY MORE COMFORTABLE SIGN AS WE LOOK TOWARDS THESE NEXT COUPLE OF DAYS. YOU KNOW, LAST WEEK WE HAD A LOT OF DAYS. WE STARTED IN THE 70S. NOT GOING TO BE THAT WAY TOMORROW MORNING. author: Business Standard
title: Australia rejects Musk's claim about govt plans to control internet access | World News - Business Standard
text:
An Australian Cabinet minister on Friday rejected X Corp owner Elon Musk's allegation that the government intended to control all Australians' access to the internet through legislation that would ban young children from social media.
Treasurer Jim Chalmers said Musk's criticism was unsurprising after the government introduced to Parliament on Thursday legislation that would fine platforms including X up to 150 million Australian dollars ($133 million) if they allow children under age 16 to hold social media accounts.
The idea that Elon Musk is not delighted with our steps to try and protect kids online is not an especially big surprise to us, nor does it trouble us greatly, Chalmers told reporters.
 The spat continues months of open hostility between the Australian government and the tech billionaire over regulators' efforts to reduce public harm from social media.
Parliament could pass legislation as soon as next week that would oblige X, TikTok, Facebook, Snapchat, Reddit and Instagram to ban young children from their platforms.
The legislation introduced on Thursday will be debated by lawmakers in Parliament on Monday.
More From This Section Russia supplied air defence missiles to N Korea in return for troops: Seoul European companies cut jobs amidst difficult economy, weak demand UK retail sales plunged more than expected before new govt's budget: ONS S Korea finds Russia supplied missiles to North Korea in return for troops COP29: 'X' factor could shape Global South's future, climate talks at Baku Musk responded to the legislation's introduction by posting on his platform, Seems like a backdoor way to control access to the Internet by all Australians.
Asked if that was the government's intention, Chalmers replied, Of course not.
Elon Musk having that view about protecting kids online is entirely unsurprising to us. He's expressed similar views before, Chalmers said.
Our job is not to come up with a social media policy to please Elon Musk. Our job is to put in place the necessary protection for kids online, Chalmers added.
In April, Musk accused Australia of censorship after an Australian judge temporarily ruled that X must block users worldwide from accessing a video of a bishop being stabbed in a Sydney church.
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese responded by describing Musk as an arrogant billionaire who considered himself above the law and was out of touch with the public.
Australian eSafety Commissioner Julie Inman Grant, the online safety watchdog who brought the court case against X, has said the legal battle led to online attacks against her and her family, including the release online of personal information without her permission, known as doxxing.
She said Musk had issued a dog whistle to 181 million users around the globe which resulted in her receiving death threats.
(Only the headline and picture of this report may have been reworked by the Business Standard staff; the rest of the content is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)

author: Bonny Matejowsky
title: Greenacres fire destroys seven homes in Omak; residents look ahead to recovery
text:
Greenacres fire destroys seven homes in Omak; residents look ahead to recovery
OMAK ‚Äì Geoffrey Pearson drove to his property Monday night unsure if his house would still be standing.
He and his family had evacuated just hours before, passing neighbors‚Äô houses engulfed in flames and black smoke.
Luckily, his home was was mostly intact, albeit with windows severely smoke damaged and several fallen fence posts.
His mother‚Äôs residence was less fortunate. A wildfire destroyed the floors of her 18-year-old house, burning various items and furniture along the way.
Pearson reviewed the damage while walking around his mother‚Äôs property Wednesday afternoon, pausing to look at the gaping hole in a bedroom wall that responders knocked in to fight the fire.
‚ÄúThat was in my bedroom when I was a kid,‚Äù he chuckled, pointing to a melted plastic alarm clock sitting atop a damaged wooden table.
Her luscious green lawn was now a sandy brown due to the heat from the fire. Rows of plants in raised-bed gardens became wilted and yellowed. Piles of ash and splinters submerged in her above-ground pool completely coated it‚Äôs tiled floor.
‚ÄúWe feel very fortunate,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe know there‚Äôs other people that are hurting a lot worse than we are.‚Äù
Their properties are just some of the those damaged in Okanogan County by the Greenacres fire, a fast-moving wildfire that started on county land Monday afternoon, destroying seven homes and 13 other structures.
The fire reached 1,013 acres and as of Wednesday is considered 50% contained. It‚Äôs cause remains under investigation.
Pearson was having a normal day at home when he noticed a wind so strong that it was shaking his house. Then, his wife Jocelyn spotted a fire just a few miles away, inching its way toward their property.
‚ÄúThen all of the sudden, the wind changed, and it went just right at us,‚Äù Pearson said.
Though neither his nor his mother‚Äôs home is completely destroyed, they have a long way to go until they can safely live in either.
Yet they have no plans to give up on their property.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be here,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll definitely make sure we have a better lawn and I won‚Äôt let sagebrush grow back on our property, but we love this community.‚Äù
The majority of the wildfire‚Äôs damage stretched along its namesake, Greenacres Road.
Wednesday, the single-lane road‚Äôs scenery was a mix of pockets of short tan brush followed by stretches of blackened grass and foliage. Some houses along the drive were reduced to charred rubble. Other properties were covered in flame retardant, sparing the land from the flames but immersing it in hot-pink dust.
Flora Rogers, a born and raised Omak resident, was working at her job at city hall when she heard her supervisor‚Äôs scanner mention a fire on Greenacres road, the same road she lives along.
She raced to her property, following a fire truck and followed by a customer of hers who volunteered to help.
Rogers, along with her boyfriend Jason and more than a dozen community members and firefighters, worked throughout the night to keep the flames at bay and protect their neighbor‚Äôs property.
‚ÄúSometimes it‚Äôs very hard to think, because you just can‚Äôt quite comprehend what you‚Äôre seeing,‚Äù Rogers said. ‚ÄúThe only thing you can do is your best. And it just kept coming.‚Äù
In the end, her house stayed intact. But the fire didn‚Äôt leave without a cost.
It killed one of her beloved cats, and destroyed thousands of dollars worth of building materials and fencing.
‚ÄúThere was a point where it had gotten really bad. You could not breathe. There was so much debris and dust in the air,‚Äù Rogers said
Rogers has been through this before. Ten years ago the Okanogan Complex fires caused by lightning strikes burned over 300,000 acres of land, including the same property she lives on today.
Though the experience was scary, she was deeply impressed by the work the firefighters put in to stop the fire and save her house. Wanting to give back, she signed up to be a volunteer firefighter at 51 years old with no previous experience, and has been helping out ever since.
This year, she made sure her yard was prepared. She cultivated a large green space, used rocks instead of mulch and kept flammable items away from her house‚Äôs exterior. She also frequently weed-wacked the areas around her fence and power lines, maintaining a perimeter of shortened brush that can be extinguished easily.
Though her prevention tactics made a difference, Rogers credits Omak‚Äôs strong community and the fast work of firefighting teams to preventing the fire from spreading futher.
‚ÄúThis county has the best people out there working and I think it‚Äôs because they are protecting their friends and their family,‚Äù Rogers said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre very, very luck to have those resources come in.‚Äù
Guy Gifford, a public information officer at the Washington Department of Natural Resources, emphasized the need for preparation when it comes to wildfires.
Embers are the leading cause of home ignition. Since these can travel through the wind and land outside your house, it‚Äôs important to minimize the amount of flammable objects that are next to the house, he said. This includes brooms, newspapers, boxes and anything else that can easily catch on fire.
‚ÄúJust being aware of the things that if I took a match to it would have caught on fire,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThink of all of those the next time you walk around a house.‚Äù
Another aspect people should be cautious about is running sprinklers from public water systems during wildfires, he said.
‚ÄúIf we all did that in my neighborhood, there‚Äôd be no water for the hydrants,‚Äù he said. We don‚Äôt really encourage people on public systems to run sprinklers because that takes away from the firefighters.‚Äù

author: Greg Biggins
title: Four-Star WR Jaime Ffrench added to the 2025 Polynesian Bowl
text: The 2025 Polynesian Bowl added another big-time player to this year's roster when Jacksonville (Fla.) Mandarin wide receiver [Jaime Ffrench](/Player/jaime-ffrench-46117166/) announced his commitment to this year's game. Ffrench is one of the nation‚Äôs top prospects, regardless of position. He‚Äôs rated the No. 30 player nationally in the Top247 and No. 13 in the 247Sports Composite. He‚Äôs coming off a dominant performance at the recent All-American Bowl Combine where he earned ‚ÄòAlpha Dog‚Äô honors as the top overall performer in the event. He‚Äôs a dynamic pass catcher who can get easy separation and was turning opposing corners around all day. He had a big junior season, hauling in 62 passes for 1,247 yards and 14 touchdowns and has the talent to play for any school in the country. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very pumped and blessed at this opportunity,‚Äù Ffrench said. ‚ÄúI know there has been a great players who played in the game in the past and I‚Äôm excited to put my name in there as a stamp as well. ‚ÄúThis will be my first time visiting Hawaii so I‚Äôm excited about that as well. I know it‚Äôs going to be a breath taking experience for me.‚Äù A big part of the Polynesian Bowl is the opportunity for the players to learn a new culture and it‚Äôs something Ffrench said he‚Äôs looking forward to as well. ‚ÄúYeh for sure, we talked about that,‚Äù Ffrench said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm definitely looking forward to that part of and I can‚Äôt wait. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve watched the game the last few years and really enjoyed it. It‚Äôs what got me interested, just seeing some of the great players that have played in so I‚Äôm excited to be a part of that.‚Äù The Polynesian Bowl has become one of the premier high school all-star games in the nation. The celebration of culture and football is what makes the game unique. The 2025 Polynesian Bowl will be televised live on the NFL Network. ‚ÄúThe Polynesian Bowl has become the hottest high school football all-star invitation,‚Äù said 4x Super Bowl Champion and Polynesian Football Hall of Fame Chairman Jesse Sapolu. ‚ÄúJaime will have an experience of a lifetime.‚Äù On the recruiting front, French was a one time commitment to Alabama but backed off in mid-January following Nick Saban‚Äôs retirement. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt set up any of my official visits yet but I have a lot of unofficial trips locked in right now,‚Äù Ffrench said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to visit LSU March 9, Ohio State March 30) Texas April 6 and Tennessee April 8. I‚Äôll most likely visit Florida State on March 23 as well. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still figuring out my official trips but I do plan to make a summer decision. Once I take my unofficial trips, I‚Äôll decide on the official trips and then be ready to make a commitment before my senior year.‚Äù Since his de-commitment, there has been a lot of buzz for Florida State and Ohio State and Miami and USC are heavily involved as well in addition to the aforementioned schools he's set to visit in March and April.

author: Cathy Halloran
title: 300 jobs at risk at Carelon Global Solutions in Limerick
text:
There are concerns for the future of 300 jobs at Carelon Global Solutions Ireland which is based at the National Technology Park at Castletroy in Limerick, after the company said tonight it is considering ceasing operations there.
Carelon, formerly known as Legato Health Technologies, has had a presence in Ireland, based in Limerick, since 2021.
The company said its decision to consider its future in Ireland comes after a review of its business operations, and an examination of the changing healthcare landscape globally.
The company provides digital integrated solutions for the healthcare industry, and is involved in information technology solutions, data analytics and business process systems.
It is understood that a consultation process will begin with employees about a winddown, but it is not clear how long that process will take, or when operations at the company will finally cease.
Carelon has been in Ireland for the past four years, but also has a presence in India, the Philippines and Puerto Rico. It is part of the larger Elevance Health group which owns a number of health organisations involved in the commercial and medicare areas, including the Anthem Blue cross and Blue Shield company, and the Wellpoint company.
In a statement tonight the company said: "As part of our ongoing review of business operations and given the changing healthcare landscape, Elevance Health is considering ceasing operations of Carelon Global Solutions Ireland Limited.
"We understand this news has been difficult for associates, whose achievements and continued dedication and service are fully appreciated, and we are committed to supporting them as we work through this process."

author: Redacci√≥n Pol√≠tica
title: ‚ÄúNo es mentira‚Äù: Petro entr√≥ a la pol√©mica de la ministra de Trabajo y la empresa Van Camp‚Äôs | Noticias hoy | EL ESPECTADOR
text: A trav√©s de su cuenta de X, el presidente Gustavo Petro comparti√≥ varios mensajes sobre el choque que gener√≥ la ministra del Trabajo, Gloria In√©s Ram√≠rez, al se√±alar que la empresa de at√∫n Van Camp‚Äôs tendr√≠a colaboradores bajo supuestas malas condiciones laborales. Luego de que la compa√±√≠a se√±alara que eso no es cierto, Petro defendi√≥ la postura de Ram√≠rez y dijo que ‚Äútienen trabajadoras tercerizadas desde hace 20 a√±os‚Äù. En uno de sus trinos comparti√≥ una denuncia contra Seatech Internacional, fabricante de la marca Van Camp‚Äôs, en la que se habla de una ‚Äúactitud f√©rreamente antisindical‚Äù de la empresa y de los supuestos contratos a trav√©s de bolsas de empleo, con los que trabajar√≠an miles de empleados por 15, 16 y hasta 20 a√±os.
